title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that AGK Bank’s liabilities have increased by $9,000 and/or does not explain that Stephanie’s new $9,000 cash deposit would be counted as a $9,000 increase in demand deposits on the liability side of AGK Bank’s balance sheet.

The response states that AGK Bank’s liabilities have increased by $9,000 and explains that Stephanie’s new $9,000 cash deposit would be counted as a $9,000 increase in demand deposits on the liability side of AGK Bank’s balance sheet.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the change in required reserves for AGK Bank as $900 and/or does not show the work.

Change in Required Reserves=$9,000×10%=$900 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5B8C@

The response calculates the change in required reserves for AGK Bank as $900 and shows the work.

Change in Required Reserves=$9,000×10%=$900 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5B8C@

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the dollar value of the maximum amount of new loans AGK Bank can initially make from Stephanie’s deposit is $8,100 and/or does not explain that AGK Bank can lend out its excess reserves and Stephanie’s deposit increased excess reserves by $8,100 ( =$9,000−$900 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4217@ ).

The response states that the dollar value of the maximum amount of new loans AGK Bank can initially make from Stephanie’s deposit is $8,100 and explains that AGK Bank can lend out its excess reserves and Stephanie’s deposit increased excess reserves by $8,100 ( =$9,000−$900 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4217@ ).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the maximum amount by which the money supply can increase throughout the banking system as $81,000 and/or does not show the work.

Excess Reserves×Money Multiplier=$8,100× 1 0.1 =$81,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@650B@

The response calculates the maximum amount by which the money supply can increase throughout the banking system as $81,000 and shows the work.

Excess Reserves×Money Multiplier=$8,100× 1 0.1 =$81,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@650B@

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that aggregate demand will increase and unemployment will decrease and/or does not explain that the increase in the money supply will result in a decrease in nominal interest rates, an increase in interest-sensitive spending, an increase in aggregate demand, an increase in real output, and a decrease in unemployment.

The response states that aggregate demand will increase and unemployment will decrease and explains that the increase in the money supply will result in a decrease in nominal interest rates, an increase in interest-sensitive spending, an increase in aggregate demand, an increase in real output, and a decrease in unemployment.
